text:
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. Don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name Joseph Hammerschmidt
2. Your address Friedenstal Alta.
3. Date Sept. 26, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Checko-Slovakia Schilighan (town)
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Farmer and village tailor
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year) May 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Minnesota 1900 to 1904 North Dakota 5 months
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). 18 years
9. What were your reasons for coming West? homesteading, adventure, travel. I had only some months school in this country. So don't mind the spelling. You can't teach an old dog new tricks just to stubborn to learn.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). Drang Sang advertised the land in the Wanderer a weekly from St Paul Minn., a government agent of the land for a time. He started a colony near Humboldt a few year before. Then he made a trip to Tramping Lake and picked that land. Got another settlement called Joseph's Colony. For German Catholics. A certain lady with influence in Government wrote an article wanting to abolish settlements of the same class of people. She wanted them to go to the prairie and in the bush and get lost. The weak will inherit the earth in spite of all opposition.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Joseph Hammerschmidt
2. Your address: 806 3rd Ave., Estevan, Alta.
3. Date: July 24, 1957
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Chuckawalka, Saskatchewan (town)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Farmer and village tailor
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year): May 1907
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   Minnesota 1907 to 1909 North Dakota 5 months
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 18 years
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: Homesteading, adventure, travel. I had only recently attended school in this country, so didn't want to be behind to learn.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Reading about it.

The spelling is not consistent throughout the text.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Friends said not to go to this land.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   I went all alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Hired through to Winnipeg, then took C.P.R. to Regina.
   I didn't know of the low rates for homesteaders, paid 4 cents a mile.
   But I made up later, making many trips to Canada for low rates.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Bought meals for other hoboes who investigated my pocket book. I had a money belt under my shirt and kept only silver in my purse. Then met other young farmers going to Borden. I helped him carry a heavy suitcase containing gears for a windmill. We slept on floor in private house. He told me before hand that talked in his sleep. I woke up in the middle of night him pulling my arm. (not my leg.) He was a nice man.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Saskatoon, Borden a few days. Then I went to work on the C.N.R. as a helper on the pioneer or tracklayer. Then west of the Elbow or Redden on the Saskatchewan River to Battleford.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   East of Dramping Lake.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   In 1914 I went into the army till 1918. Then I bought land in the Peace River Country, there at Friedenstal, where I have resided since. I have a section of land here. Two big boys are running the place. Pam retired on the farm. I will try to write about a few other places where I have been on the lake.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Working on farms and woods in winter. After
   Railding sod houses in summer, doing in B.C. in winter.
   After three years I farmed with 4 oxen. Bought one good team
   at Caduce Alta, with which I started boys fall winter right there.
   Then traveled per wagon east to Dramping Lake in May 1909.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey went do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

In 1914 I went into the army till 1918. Then I bought land in Saskatchewan.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Once or twice a year

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Oliver Schonberger on 10th March 1931 at Friedenstal

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Not on my recommendation. But on Prang Gang's advertisement in the Hammerschmidt paper. A large settlement around Tramper's Lake. There are now 25 parishes. There are just as many here as there are in Europe. This settlement was started in 1912. I joined in 1918. They started with oxen here. But brought in horses from Montana.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   There are a few relatives in Ontario and in Minnesota. There are many. I was down there about 2 years ago. There are many relatives there. But most of them would never think of coming to Canada. I am the only one.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   After the track reached Battleford then came another bridge across which we could not go. I went to work with a grading outfit. The boss rode ahead on horseback to pick the trail. We got as far west as Edmonton. We had a large outfit of horses and mules and about 70 men. There was a Hotel with liquor at Edmonton. The man bought drinks and got drunk. I had to save my money. Once we slept on the Prairie for dinner. When an Indian came along with an ax to earn his living, he asked me what I knew. I knew it was against the law, they gave him wishes. He danced for the boys and said god took away big country from Indians, because he was lazy, and gave it to the white men. Then I had to travel with him. I was the youngest, and gave it to the whole men. Then I had to travel with him. I was the youngest, and gave it to the whole men.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   I was on the go all the time, building sod houses and barns, and digging wells. The church was only 4 miles from my place. I went there every Sunday on foot. Several times I went to North Dakota on threshing time, where I got from three to four dollars a day. There was a widow with 3 daughters who had a homestead. We would go there Sunday afternoon. One day she was jealous of me, and told the widow that the sod barn I had built for Mr. Speck had caved in. I had already received $25 dollars, the price for the barn, in advance. If the man comes along now with his stock, he will find no shelter. So I ran 12 miles barefoot to look, and found the barn perfect. I said nothing.
29. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Once or twice a year.

30. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Oliver John Hammerschmidt on March 10, 1931 at Bucyrus, Ohio.

21. Did anyone else come to Bashkortostan because of your recommendation? It was a place to settle.

We came here in 1948. We came from Wisconsin.

There were 25 families. We came from Illinois.

River City, Illinois, and we lived there until 1948.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

There are a few relatives in Colorado and in Minnesota. We don't know how many.

Concerning the Canadian, I am not sure.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

After the track reached Battleford, they came another stagecoach, which was called the "Great Western." We traveled with a group of about 100 men.

We had a large outfit of horses and mules, and about 700 men. There was a Hotel with a large number of rooms. The man bought them for us.

Though I knew of a young woman, they gave her to me. She was very kind.

I traveled about much in the early years. (For business, attending the church, visiting friends, etc.)

How often? How far? By what means of travel?

I went on the go all the time, building sod houses and helping with everything.

The church was only miles from my place. I went there every Sunday.

Several times I went to work in Idaho, but I was living there when I got homestead. We moved to Idaho that summer after we got married.

Still the Indians thought the railroad would build for Mr. Spence, but somehow I had already received 95 dollars. The question for the Indians was answered.

If the main comes a long way with his stock, he will find our shelter. The train will make sure of the stock and provide the train freight. We will have something to eat.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   I came with a doctor from Battleford in his car in 1913.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Bought my first car in 1929. Chevrolet

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   William Delaney had a store close to church. Got his stuff from Battleford.
   He is still living at Calahoo Alta., west of Edmonton Alta. Has over 30 years.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Some farmers brought horses from the states in 1905. Frank Sandmeyer brought every trading outfit in 1907. He bought all the farms in the country.
   Grand Trunk was built 1907. Road was made by plowing a furrow where the wagons wheels went. Prairie fires would burn holes into the ground forming hummocks, making it terrible rough.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Us a bachelor I would go once or twice weekly to buy oatmeal and flour and some belly pork. For week we would have nothing but oatmeal and dumplings.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   We knew nothing of that custom in early days. We bought some on Sundays after mass, also got the mail. Which was at the store.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   We knew nothing of that custom in early days. We bought some on Sundays after mass, also got the mail. Which was at the store.

32. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We didn't have so much money then to throw around for mail orders.
   We called these catalogues the devil's bible. They were only used in toilets. They were a great temptation for women. The course of domestic trouble. My wife has sold clothes full of thread all eaten by moths.

33. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   We had Peace River telephone in 1918 by the farmers themselves.

34. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   During Sir. Wilfrid Laurier administration we got very much attached to the country. You couldn't get standing room coming in. Afterwards, when war broke, you couldn't get standing room going out. Later I just wanted to go to the wilderness to get away from it all. From New York to Chicago to Peace River where the West and the fox say one another good night. People are not rooted in western Canada. Conditions are too uncertain.

They are only victims of exploitation.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

We sent Frank Sandmaier to Ottawa in 1910 one of 200 farmers to ask for reciprocity on farm machines. Sir Wilfrid promised to make it election platform. When much propaganda he was thrown out. Then many people started to leave the country. More would have gone but could not sell their property. I went to the United States.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

The depression in the 20s caused another exodus. New people came in, but I do not know of only one who came back and he had his farm rented, and now took it up again. The young are more content, indifferent, drifting, unwilling to work. Let tomorrow take care of itself.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I have been active for the last 20 years as entertainer, theatrical performer, musician, and singing in our parish hall and church choir.

For the next 3 years I like to keep in the background and take it easy.

I am a convinced Social Crediter, most of the time its better for me to keep my big mouth shut. I even walking down the street when one man keeps me a big kick in the butt. He said that makes fun.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

I guess I was the first who moved a house 26 x 30, 2 miles across the prairie with 2 oxen, alone. With block and tackle.

Peter Yams Jr. of Bredenstuhl lived at Tramping Lake with me. His wife was that started this settlement here in 1912. He retired on the farm here two boys is a doctor one a draftsman the other runs the farm. He is well versed and might be able to tell you many things.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Our closest town on the Grand Trunk was called Coblenz at the suggestion of a German fellow during the first war. It was changed to Cavel, the name that existed as a spy in Belgium on the Battle River. Breaks then was a bad hill that was called the Pobo Hill, after a pioneer living on the flat below. Queen him cut wheat on the first day of October. There was an old trail from Battleford to Swift Current that but a ½ stage ride. Soft footed oxen would pull out on the prairie making new cuts halfway between both towns we had the 60 miles fresh where we got our wood. Then it was hilly and sandy with slush containing water most all summer.
36. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

We send Branch Headquarters to Ottawa in the fall of 2014.

35. Did many people move away during the 1914-1918 war? Did many people return during the same period?

The discussion on the war caused another epidemic. New people came to settle out here and now we are back to the old days.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, give name, date, position, and purpose.

A friend who moved here moved his family and church services.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were able to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates whenever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I grew up the first who moved a house 26x30, 2 miles north of town.

38. How did the names get their names (school districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)?

Gives: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) changes in names since the first name was given; date and reason for change.

Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3), etc.

Our closest town on the Grand Island was called Colborne at the suggestion of a German fellow during the first war. It was changed to Carleton because that was a spy in England on the Battle River.

Besides this was a big hill that was called the Peter Hill after a fisherman living on the lake. Others have called it the Peter Hill ever since.

This was an old house from the battlefield to the nearest settlement that had a village.

Hobby was a creek which became famous for making new rails.

This was an old railroad track that ran through the area where we got our gravel. This was a very muddy river that was containing all our gravel. This river was mostly affected.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Father Ebert, a priest at North Star, Alta., has an old pamphlet that describes all the incidents of the beginning of the Tramping Lake settlement.

The churches keep close record of these things.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

........ (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Farmer Elmo Hammerschmidt, grandchild Sisbet.

at home - Joe Hammerschmidt Jr.

Mary, nurse in Fairview hospital, close by.

Ottilia at home.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

I was reluctant to change from horses to tractors, only for the boys. I consented to change to tractors and combines and swather. I said, "You will be slaves to machines, cars and banks." But so it is! Machines and repair going up, land farm produce going down. It is however, not good but man made mismanagement. So we should not take it too hard. A good thing makes good times. Social Credit could help, by creating interest free money. We still have homesteads here. People living in the bush, as poor as ever before. Winter conditions as bad as ever experienced in the early days.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

George Reiniger Leipzig, Sask.

Bill Delany Calahoo, Alta.

Sr. Pete Gans Friedenstal, Alta.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
Questions regarding historical source material:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations? (Describe.)

Pamphlet that describes all the amenities of the beginning of the Framingham Lakes settlement.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library Section or the Archives Office at the University of Saskatchewan?

If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here!
Dear friends,

I want to relate my experience with my homestead.

Let me make it clear at the very beginning that adventure is what I wanted, and it was what I got. Now if there had been stories about any place in my native town, I would have traveled over the prairie to miles a day (not every day). I traveled over the prairie to miles a day (not every day).

After arriving in Shoshone on May 19th, we soon found a man who wanted to go to Wyoming Lake. We had been there for a week or so. A priest would accompany us until we could find a place to settle. We met the young priest at the train station.

The priest was the only man in the bunch. I couldn't go along for I did not have money enough to start farming. So the best thing for me to do was to work for months and then build a shack.

Filled on my homestead until and unless within an age of William Ross in Portland. Each settler gave $13 dollars towards building the church. George Reisinger my countryman let the expectation. He is still at the same place. After everything with the steel gang for 2 months as a worker, I went with a grading outfit. At Longview we met the bar colonists who had come there the year before. The railroad was built expressly for them. I met the English locomotive engineer on the prairie, feasting three weeks plenty bottles. I heard hilarious laughter. We slept over a badger well. Seems fair to face with the English Cristo-gracy. With my bundle on my back I looked at them, for a brief moment. They saw me. Then I turned around and walked away.

coincident, one which made a lasting impression on my mind. The government could issue the money and build all the railroads. Then we would not have to pay extra for the passage.
Dear friends I want to relate my experience with my homestead.

Let me make it clear at the very beginning that adventure was not what I wanted, and it was not. None of these hard luck stories have any place in my narrative. I was young and full of fury. I traveled over the prairie 60 miles a day (not every day) on foot. I was able to go the distance.

After arriving in Salt Lake City, we went to the town of Salt Lake City. We had been there for a week or so. We would wait until the first pioneers to the new homes. Some of the farmers who had money would settle there. We met the young priest at the Town. He said he would be forward to the trip with great anticipation.

The priest was the only man in the church. I could not go alone. For God did not have money enough to start farming. So the best thing for me to do was to work for six months and then build a shack.

I filled on my homestead now. It was done within an age.

William Brown Norton. Each settler gave us dollars towards building the church. George Reining my countryman let the expectation. He is still at the same place. After working with the steel gang for two weeks, we met the bear colonists, who had come there the year before. The railroad was built expressly for them. We met the English immigrants gathered on the prairie, feasting. They were plenty bottles. I heard hilarious laughter. We slept over a bedraggled noble farms face to face with the English Christo-gravity. With my bundle on my back I looked at them, for a brief moment. They saw me. Then I turned around and came back again.

They said, "We will meet a lasting impression for our convenience, one which would last a lifetime." They were right. We would build all our mind. The government could not see the money and build all.
The English settler were not satisfied. It seems they expected a white house and a red barn on their places.

One of them shouted at me: God bring success upon the man that brought us into this god forsaken country to starve to death. We could get drunk at Fogelman's, Owen's, the only ones that had a gun but no ammunition, or we would have shot up the town. Pay on your English man for a.

We could tell them by their liberty chopped up except.

When over the boys got time, I would accompany them out into the country looking for land. There was black soil and grass three deep. I had my land, or I would have taken some weight there. One day at morning time a wagon got stuck in a wet place. We hitched 4 horses on the back. As it jerked back, the front wheels jerked and the wagon tipped over. There was a great shout: man under the load! We threw plows and therapies in all directions, and found the poor fellow with a rope broken arm. There was a dealer somewhere on the 200 mile line, but where? East or west. Both boys took the buckey and went first west to the next outlet. Then he found out that the dealer was east, so he took the enlarged map away with the buckey the next morning. I learned later, that one could alleviate the pain by putting hot and cold towels, dirt in hot and cold water on the swollen part, changing this often continuously. The swelling gets blue and more heat. This is well to remember. Jimmy says a little or at least alleviated much pain. This is what is called the water treatment. You must be done at once after the accident. Be sure to make it plenty hot.
The English settler where not satisfied. It seems they expected a white house and a red barn on their places.

One of them shouted at me: God bring success upon the man that brought him into this god forsaken country to save us to dead. We'll go down at Plymouth. Our only son that had a gun but no ammunition, or we would have shot up the town. Pray for your English man, for a

We could tell them by their dirty chopped up except.

When own the boys got time, I would accompany them out into the country looking for land. There was black soil and grass fence deep. I had my land, or I would have taken some weight there. One day at morning time a wagon got stuck in a new place. We hitched horses on the back. As it jumbled back,

the front wheels jack knifed and the wagon tipped over. There was a great shout: man under the load! We threw plows and themselves in all directions, and found the feet fellow with a rope broken arm. There was a doubt somewhere on the 200 mile line but where? East or west. Both the corn took the buckey and went first west to the next outlet. Then he found out that the dealer was east so he took the improved manner away with the buckey the next morning. I learned later that once could alleviate the pain by putting hot and cold towels, dirt in hot and cold water on the swollen part.

Changing this continuously. If the swelling gets blue apply more heat. This is well to remember. Always save a life or at least alleviate much pain. This is what is called the water treatment. Opiates be done at once after the accident. Be sure to make it plenty hot.
The English settler when not satisfied. Of seems they expected a white house and a red barn on their places.

One of them shouted at me: God being outers open the man that brought us into this god forsaken country to starve to death. We'll hang you at Fort Smith, if we can find the only one that had a gun, but no ammunition, so we could have shot up the town. Pay to you Englishman far-a.

We could tell them by their ability chopped up except.

When even the boys got home, I would accompany them out into the country looking for land. There was black soil until grass fence deep. I had my land or I would have taken some weight there. One day at morning time a wagon got stuck in a muddy puddle. We hitched horses on the back of it jerked back, the front wheels jack-knifed and the wagon tipped over. There was a great shout: man under the load! We threw plows and scrapers in all directions. There was a doctor somewhere on the 200 mile line, but where? East or west. Both men took the buckshot and went first west to the next outfit. Please found out that the doctor was east. So he took the wounded man away with the buckshot the next morning. I learned little. That our could alleviate the pain by putting hot and cold towels, slight in hot and cold water on the swollen part, changing this continuously. With swelling get blues apply more heat. This is well to remember. You may save a life or at least alleviate much pain. Pain which is called the water treatment. Opium is done at once after the accident. Be sure to make it plenty hot.
The English settler was not satisfied. It seems they expected a white house and a red barn on their places.

One of them thought at one: God being out of the man that brought him into this godless country to starve to death. Our Lord got church at Southampton. Over the only one that had a gun but no ammunition, so we would have shot up the town. Pay on you Englishman far.

When own the Englishmen would accompany them out into the county looking for land. This was black soil and grass nine deep. Had any land, or ground, would have taken some weight there. One day at morning time a roughy got stuck in a new place. We hitched horses on the back as it jerked back.

There was one big thunderstorm that took all our tents down except our sleeping tent which we had thrown by sheer force. After two months with grinding out felt, it was time for me to go back to my homestead to build my shelterhouse. Back to Battleford 200 miles away. I figured the best way would be to go on the Saskatchewan river that flows past that town. I bought my canoe, which I could easily carry in Battleford. I traveled north to the river and made a raft, covered it with spruce bows and set her adrift. I spread my blankets on top and went to sleep. When I woke up, I took my long pole to see how deep the water was and—umph! I was stuck in a sandbar.

This happened several times during the night. Each time I had to get out, carry food and light and push with all my might to get the raft free again. Next night it started to rain. I found a nice spot at an overhanging branch. Leaning on a place I lined it with spruce bows. I placed my blankets on it and went to sleep. Often waking up, I heard foxes barking along the river banks and the water boiling from the rain.

Poveshell came loose from the overhanging branch. Showers of sand and gravel would settle down. I was on the go—two day break. In 1913 I went to work on the Grand Trunk furnishing the telegraph line into Prince Rupert. Then a mining town, now on the coast. When the job was done I started my travel into Alaska and the Yukon. The wages were better there, $15 dollars a month, that I could not make anywhere else. In Alaska the currency was all gold coins. I got a job doing road work in the mountains.
